Freedom and Responsibility in Broadcasting is the theme of
this year's Institute for Education by Radio-Television. In this
and the suceeding sessions of the Institute, many people will
examine that basic problem from many points of view. The approach
taken here is an international one: what can we learn from the
experiences of radio and television broadcasters in Europe
about Freedom and Responsibility in Broadcasting?
I
After some long and frank talks with broadcasters in the
Soviet Union, I wrote out a one-sentence description of Soviet
broadcasting. The top policy officials of radio and television
in Moscow, Leningrad, Tblisi and Kiev all approved it. The
statement was as followsg
"Support of the basic ideologies of Communism9 of the
Communist Party, and of current government policies and practices,
is the principal, underlying and continuing objective of all
Soviet broadcasting 0n
Hardly our attitude, is it? But a superficial look at
certain aspects of broadcasting in the United Kingdom, reveals
what at first may appear as an equally alarming state of affairs.
The governing boards of both the British Broadcasting Corporation
and the Independent Television Authority are appointed by the
government* and may be dismissed at will* The BBC°s License
declares that the Corporation must broadcast any announcement
which any government department requests it to broadcast* and
that the Postmaster General may veto any single program or class
of programso Provisions in the Television Act of 1954 extend the
same controls to Britain®s other broadcasting organization,, the ITA*
